page.title: 02GENERAL LANDSCAPE.
page.content: The landscape around the village is mainly open views of rolling hills divided into fields of 6 acres or more by hedges of hawthorn or wire fences. In places trees have been allowed to grow up in the hedgerows. Many fields are left down to pasture for the cattle and the sheep, but about half are cropped for cereals, broad beans or oilseed rape. The meandering paths of Whitsun Brook and its tributaries are marked by the lines of willows and bushes, providing a vital shelter belt for wildlife. Bishampton church at the northern end of the village can be seen from most of the area whereas the 13th century Throckmorton Chaplery (a virtually unrestored church) is sited in a field and is a much less prominent feature.
